transcripts.text: Please welcome Andrew Yang.

Well, Mr.  Yang, I was telling you I have a dear friend who's part of the Yang gang and is riding very hard for you.  So he's very excited.  you're on today.  So you, I was first really introduced to you in the last debate, but there's a controversy going on right now because you accused NBC of cutting your mic off at times when you wanted to interject.  NBC has denied that's happened, but it's a big conspiracy all over the internet.  Can you clarify what happened?

Well, I was only asked two questions over two hours, and that's, you know, like, there for everyone to see.  And so I just shared my experience with some supporters after the fact.  But we're just thrilled that I have another debate in July and then also in September and October to keep getting our ideas out to the American people.
But how do you make it so you don't speak, you speak more than three minutes?
Well, we were joking that maybe I'd have like a sign or something to hold it up.  But we're very confident that we'll get more opportunities.
Were you the only one that happened to?  Or did somebody else also get screwed out?
I think one of the other candidates said that her mic was also cut at various times.  Marianne Williamson?  Yeah, I think that's right.  I haven't talked to Marianne about it, though.

because he spoke less than three minutes, or about three minutes, but you have some very dedicated followers.  They call themselves the Yang Gang.  Supporters wear hats that have math written across the top.  Make America think harder.  Uh... Crowd chant PowerPoints at your rallies.  And there's a YouTube channel dedicated to getting you elected called Nerds for Andrew Young 2020.  So, and I love that, actually, because I do think that, you know, I give a lot of credit to the American people.  I think we're smarter than people are giving us credit for.  And that's what I think you're trying to tap into.  So tell us about that.

Well, my campaign's dedicated to trying to solve the problems that got Donald Trump elected.  We're in the midst of the greatest economic transformation in the history of our country, what experts are calling the Fourth Industrial Revolution.  And so Make America Think Harder is trying to get America focused on the fact that it's certainly not immigrants that are causing these problems.  It's the fact that technology is pushing our economy to a point where more and more Americans are having a harder time finding paths forward.  Amazon's closing 30% of our malls and stores in the next four years.  And being a retail worker is still the most common job in this country.  The average retail worker is a 39-year-old woman making between $9 and $10 an hour.  We know she doesn't have much in the way of savings.  So as her stores close, the opportunities disappear.  We have to start focusing on solving those problems, and that's what makes America think harder.  It's the opposite of this call to yesteryear.  We need to start solving the problems of today.
Is anybody in the Republican Party giving any thought to what you just said?

Well, when you talk to politicians about this economic transformation we're in the midst of, unfortunately, a lot of the solutions revolve around education and retraining.  But I looked into the studies around retraining manufacturing workers in the Midwest, and the results were very, very bad.  Zero to 15% success rate.  So if you're a politician and you say, hey, we're going to educate Americans for the jobs of the future, then everyone's like, okay, that sounds great.  But then when you dig into the reality, unfortunately, that's not the way it works out.

Well, it didn't work, right?  Because we tried to do that when we moved mining.  We said we were going to retrain people, and it didn't work, as we heard from various people saying, well, there's nothing out there for me.

Well, when they're climate deniers also, they don't even look at the possibility of having green jobs, which a lot of people could go into that.  But anyway, you are also proposing something of a basic universal income, a freedom dividend, you call it.  What does that mean exactly?

So this is an idea that's been with America since our founding.  Thomas Paine was for it.  Martin Luther King championed it in 1967.  It's a dividend for every American as a right of citizenship.  So under my plan, every American adult would receive $1,000 a month starting at age 18 every month until you expire.  What?  Yes.  Yeah.

That will cost $3 trillion.  Where's this money coming from?  And what is the point of it, really?  They say if you give a man a fish, if you give a man a fishing line, he can fish.  If you give him one fish, he'll just eat that fish.  Something like that.
I think I know the saying you're talking about.  How does it go?  How does it go?  You know that one?  So you hand somebody $1,000.  Now, what good is that?  They spend the $1,000.
It's a game-changer, though, for people that are struggling.
I know it's a bit of a game-changer, but it's not a long-term solution.

Come on.  It actually would help build a more human-centered economy, what I call the trickle-up economy, because it would allow more people to do the kind of work that they want to do, including people like my wife, who's at home with our two young boys, one of whom is autistic.  And right now, the market values her work at zero.  GDP values her work at zero.  If you start putting resource into our hands, it actually expands what we think of as work.
Well, now you're talking about paying women for doing housework and doing work at home, being mothers.  That's a good idea.
That is a good idea.

That's different.  That's different.  Well, I mean, again, and this is... This is a game changer for the waitress at the diner who's getting harassed by her boss.  It's a game changer for the single mom who's stuck in an abusive relationship.  Like, we need to put the economic resources into people's hands to be able to improve their situation.

But still, how are you going to pay for this exactly?  You know, listen to Elizabeth Warren.  She's got a plan.  She's charging 2% over certain millions and millions and millions.  What are you going to do?

So my plan is to get the resources from the big winners of the 21st century economy.  So the big winners are who?  Amazon, trillion-dollar company, paid zero in taxes, less than everyone in this room.  Apple, Netflix, Google.  These companies are great at just not paying a whole lot of taxes.  Right.  And so what you do is you have to look around the world and see that other countries have put a mechanism in place.  so the American people get a tiny slice of every Amazon sale, every Google search, every Facebook ad, every Uber mile.  And that's enough to pay for a dividend of $1,000 a month.  particularly because this money just comes back to us over and over again.
Yeah, but you're assuming that those companies are just going to go on ad infinitum, making, making, making millions and millions.

With all due respect, as the millennial at the table, I would love any... What about me?  I'm a millennial.  Okay, excuse me, it's Joy and I as the millennials at the table.  But every Democrat that comes on, the answer is write a check.  And the problem is, the deficit is going to my generation, and that's already the problem right now.  So is there any answer to anything?  Wait a minute, who created that deficit?  I'm asking the presidential candidate this question, if you don't mind.
I don't mind, but I want to answer it anyway.
Do you have an answer?  that is... Okay.  Go ahead.  Sir, you can answer.

No, no, no.  No, please.  I understand the question.  And so I've run companies, and you have a revenue problem in this country, and you have an expense problem in this country.  You have to go after both of them.  But the big winner, so if you have artificial intelligence that Amazon's investing billions of dollars in, could displace 3.5 million truck drivers.  Right now, it's the most common job in 29 states.  The amount of value that gets generated from that immense, almost unbelievable, and right now the American people will get zero of that value.  So if you put a mechanism in place, you can actually generate hundreds of billions of dollars.
Wait, hold on, hold on, hold on, because we're going to take a break, but we're coming right back.  Stick around.  He's going to stick around.

You stick around, too.  To get to know more about your policies, let's do a lightning speed round with you.  Sure.  Universal Health Care, yes or no?  Yes.  Robert Mueller is set to testify July 17th.  Should Congress start impeachment hearings?
We'd have to wait until his testimony, but I'm thrilled that he's going to be testifying for Congress.
What would he say that would change your mind to a definite yes?
You know, I'd have to see what the facts were.  Also, I've been trying to put it on Congress to make that determination, really, because that's their job.
Okay.  Closing the wealth gap, especially when it comes to the African-American community.  Reparations a part of that?

Well, Martin Luther King championed a dividend for all Americans.  I think that's where we should start, $1,000 a month for every American.  And then reparations is a whole separate issue, because the $1,000 dividend doesn't address the historical legacy of slavery.
Why should rich white people get $1,000 a month?
Well, the great thing is that it will remind them that they're still an American.
But in Alaska, they have a dividend.  No one at this table needs an extra $1,000 a month.
But in Alaska, they have a dividend of $1,000.  Well, I wouldn't feel right when there are still veterans on the street.
You could give it away.

That's what you could use it away.  You could give it away to charity.  That's what he means when he says.  it reminds you you're an American.  It's not just about what you do for yourself, it's what you do for other folks.

And in Alaska, they give a dividend to everyone in Alaska from the petroleum fund, $1,000 to $2,000 a year, and it depoliticizes it, it destigmatizes it, it's just everyone gets it, and so there's no, like, oh, you get it, I don't.
Right.  Immigration.
I'm the son of immigrants myself.  I think we need to create a path to citizenship over the long term.
So you also have some unusual and I would say unorthodox stances as well.  You came out against circumcision, correct?

Well, you know, I think parents need to educate themselves on what the health information is.  You know, my wife and I obviously made a certain determination, but it should be in the hands of parents.
In the hands of what?
The parents.  Because when you have a male baby, they just toss it on you.
Well, they try to.
They try to just toss it on you.  Yeah, they try to.
You also believe in free marriage counseling?

Yeah, the data shows that if you grow up in a two-parent household, certain outcomes are more likely.  And so from a societal perspective, it makes perfect sense to try and keep couples together if they want to stay together.
So would that just be like a social worker for every couple in America?
Well, it'd be like marriage counseling, you know, stipend, essentially, where it's like.  if you decide to seek marriage counseling, then they can just go and get paid by...

My version of marriage counseling is drinking Jack Daniels, shooting some guns, and hanging out.  So, like, my version is different than... It works.  No, just like going to a range.  So I'm just saying, like, this universal peg for every hole is always my problem with the left right now.  There is not a... Every American is different.  Every American does things in different ways.  Oh, yeah.  So I would say... I don't know.  You also believe in staffing a White House psychologist.  That's an idea.
We need to destigmatize mental health issues in this country generally.  And so if we have a psychologist in the White House, I thought it was a good idea before the current administration.
Do you think that he's capable of even doing such a thing?
You know what?  It doesn't even matter.
We'll have one in my administration.  That's right.
Thanks to Andrew Yang.
Really interesting.  I'm going to keep an eye on you.
We'll be right back.
